ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: dictation, sightsinging, harmony, ear training, interval identification
I improved my sight-singing and dictation. I also got better at recognizing chord progressions in different types of music.
sight singing skills, more music theory knowledge

I learned how to sight sing in solfege, recognize chords, and about different kinds of harmony and melodies. I knew some of the material covered previously but this class really strengthened my skills in all these areas.
Much better understanding of solfege, sight singing, and interval recognition. I learned how to transcribe by ear.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: low workload. Weaknesses: the class gives an unfair amount of advantage to people with perfect pitch.

Strengths: The class was relatively low workload and not stressful. I also genuinely improved in my aural skills abilities
.
Weaknesses: We would often start class 5-10 minutes late and not get through the material we needed to cover that day. We would also often repeat exercises that weren't as useful to aural skills. For example, we spent way too much time on octave identification in isolation rather than practicing dictation and how octave identification is used in context. The class came from a wide range of backgrounds, so the professor would often have to explain very simple music theory concepts that I thought were prereqs for the course. I had taken AP Music Theory before this course, and I felt bored in class a lot since we would spend so much time on how to read notes on a grand staff, which was supposedly a prereq for the course. It did not really feel like a 200-level course because of this, and some more advanced concepts were glossed over. The tests also did not feel very representative of what we learned in class (the class was asking what the difference between seventh chords were during the final, which was one of the concepts tested), and the extra credit on the exams was entirely dependent on having prior knowledge of inversions that we had never talked about in class. I also expected to learn more about improvisation since it was on the syllabus, but we barely covered it.
less nitpicky with grades, more opportunity for grade improvement

Strengths: great for practicing aural skills, good activities for practice, assessments matched the material and pace of the course. Weaknesses: the class times were short and sometimes it felt like not a ton was covered in the amount of time that we hadI would have appreciated a little bit of a faster pace during the class times themselves.
It was a pretty engaging class and didn't jump from topic to topic

Strengths: small class size and welcoming environment made it easier to learn new skills, and I appreciate that the class accommodates a range of abilities. Weaknesses: somewhat unstructured, and a lack of clear goals sometimes made it difficult to know what to practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The course is a gut if you've taken AP Music Theory or have done any amount of aural skills training in the past. However, if you want to actually challenge yourself, you might want to take a more advanced class.
yes, if they want to take a nice music class
Yes! I think this class is a great introduction to aural skills if you already have some knowledge of music.
Yes, it was a really good review of aural skills.
Yes, it's the perfect course to take if you want an intermediate level music theory course.

I would highly recommend this course! Just for the reason of taking a course where you spend class time singing, I would recommend it. I took this class as a senior majoring in economics, and it really pushed me out of my comfort zone. This class teaches skills that have to be practiced, and the amount of material there was to learn and practice felt a bit insurmountable. However, I improved a lot throughout the course, and I am very glad that I now have a better music theory foundation!

extras.title: MUSI 218 01 - Aural Skills for Tonal Music
